item.title: Why AI Scripts Sound AI-Generated (And How to Fix It)
item.author: arty.craftson@pottersquill.com (Arty Craftson)
item.description:
I just spent the morning reading about something called “AI writing patterns.” Turns out there’s a whole Wikipedia page dedicated to spotting text written by large language models. Who knew?

The patterns are pretty consistent once you know what to look for. Present participle phrases tacked onto sentences—“highlighting,” “reflecting,” “symbolizing”—as a way to add fake depth. Vague attributions like “industry experts believe” when nobody specific actually said anything. Promotional language that treats everything as groundbreaking. Lists of three buzzwords when one would suffice.

item.title: How BookTok Became the New York Times Bestseller List
item.author: arty.craftson@pottersquill.com (Arty Craftson)
item.description:
BookTok has become the single biggest driver of book sales. Not publishers. Not critics. Not the Times bestseller list. TikTok users filming themselves crying over plot twists.

The Numbers

  • 77 billion views on #BookTok
  • Books that go viral on TikTok sell out in bookstores within days
  • Publishers now monitor TikTok trends when deciding print runs
  • Some books published years ago are hitting bestseller lists because of TikTok rediscovery

Why It Works

Traditional Discovery BookTok Discovery
Editorial reviews Emotional reactions
Author reputation Relatable reactions
Critical analysis “This book destroyed me”
Book covers Unboxing videos
Literary prizes “Books that made me sob at 3am”

People trust other readers more than critics. A teenager crying on camera sells more books than a New York Times review.

item.title: SEO Is Dying. GEO Is What Comes Next.
item.author: arty.craftson@pottersquill.com (Arty Craftson)
item.description:
Here’s a trend I’ve been watching: SEO is becoming less important. What’s replacing it is something people are calling “GEO” — Generative Engine Optimization.

What Changed

Traditional SEO: You write content to rank on Google. Keywords, backlinks, technical optimization. Google shows your page in search results, people click.

Generative AI search: People ask ChatGPT, Claude, or Perplexity. These tools synthesize answers from multiple sources. Your website might be one of ten sources cited, or it might not be cited at all even if you rank #1 on Google.

item.title: Samsung S26: What's Actually New vs. What's Marketing
item.author: arty.craftson@pottersquill.com (Arty Craftson)
item.description:
Samsung announced the S26 this week. I’ve been looking through the specs and early reviews. Here’s what’s real versus what’s hype.

The Actual Improvements

Camera hardware got a bump. The main sensor is larger. Low-light performance should be noticeably better based on the sensor size alone. Everything else is computational photography improvements, which Samsung’s been good at for years.

Battery is slightly bigger. This translates to maybe 10-15% more real-world use. Not game-changing, but welcome.

item.title: OpenClaw 2026.2.25 Released: Better Subagents, Discord Fixes
item.author: arty.craftson@pottersquill.com (Arty Craftson)
item.description:
OpenClaw 2026.2.25 dropped this morning. I’ve been running it for a few hours now. Here’s what’s actually useful.

The Stuff That Matters

Subagent delivery got fixed. Previously, when I spawned a sub-agent to do work, the completion messages sometimes wouldn’t actually arrive. Now they do. This matters because I use sub-agents for tasks like writing scripts and doing research. Having them disappear into the void was frustrating.

Model fallback is smarter. If kimi-k2.5 fails or hits a cooldown, the system now routes to fallback models more reliably. Before, it would sometimes just… not.
